text.0:
Together we can:

:white_circle: Protect more people in the UK from bad information

:white_circle: Stop the spread of vaccine misinformation and other false claims

:white_circle: Help stand up for honesty in politics and media

One donation = double the impact :backhand_index_pointing_right: https://t.co/MoCTL34ozf #honest2021 https://t.co/N0e2Q4F0kJ
text.1:
But, by 26 November, the number of people in hospital had flattened. 

So what appears to have happened is, in an attempt to highlight cherry-picking, the Telegraph has cherry-picked data. [6/6]

Our fact check in full :backhand_index_pointing_down:
https://t.co/mJKtZQs5Vc
text.2:
But the situation on 31 October was very different to that on 26 November.

On 31 October, the rising number of beds occupied by patients with Covid in various hospitals, reflected the fact that Covid hospitalisations were rising across the country, as their slides showed. [5/6] https://t.co/yimhkLC1Tq
text.3:
Now, back on 31 October, the slides at the daily briefing did show figures from individual hospitals specifically affected by rising Covid-19 cases. 

This may have been what Ms Pearson was referring to. [4/6] https://t.co/CW9KwYbJQj
text.4: At no point during the last week have we found any mention from the two advisors of bed occupancy problems in specific hospitals. [3/6]
text.5:
At the daily briefing on 26 November Sir Patrick and Professor Whitty made no mention of bed capacity at individual hospital trusts.

Sir Patrick noted that, at a national level, the number of Covid-19 patients in hospitals had “flattened.” [2/6]
text.6:
Telegraph columnist Allison Pearson claimed that, last week, Sir Patrick Vallance and Chris Whitty presented cherry-picked figures from hospitals on course to run out of beds, despite falling or stable numbers of Covid patients in hospital.

The problem? They didn’t.

[Thread]:backhand_index_pointing_down:
text.7:
Unsubstantiated claims and conspiracy theories about vaccines risk prolonging the pandemic, and costing lives.

This week we need your support for a more honest 2021 in the Big Give Christmas Challenge.

One donation = double the impact :backhand_index_pointing_right: https://t.co/MoCTL3lZqN #honest2021 https://t.co/BihEiZWm8u
text.8:
We’re starting to see a pattern of Freedom of Information requests on Covid-19 deaths being sent to NHS trusts who are unlikely to deal with serious Covid-19 cases :backhand_index_pointing_down:

https://t.co/8ftQdUlqAe
